Partners have been implementing SOMJR activities in these regions and locations since 2019 (Awdal, Sool, Sanaag) and 2020 (Bari, Mudug), and were able to invest in the resilience building of target communities. Bocaame in Sool has been added as a new location to the SOMJR: it has already been targeted by partner KAALO during the DRA-funded Desert Locust Joint Response (May to October 2020), however, needs remain high as Bocaame is highly affected by insecurity and recurring waves of desert locust invasions.

title: Somalia Joint Response 2021
description:
Somalia’s population is currently experiencing multiple shocks (‘triple threat’ – locust, drought, COVID-19): the Desert Locust upsurge that started in late 2019  and continues to threaten the food security and livelihoods of pastoralists and farmers in many parts of the country; riverine and flash floods that affect the food security, livelihoods and safety of farmers and people living in flood-prone, populated areas; the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic that is having severe health and socio-economic impacts both in Somalia and globally; and the extended impact of previous shocks (flooding, drought, displacement, etc.) on livelihoods.
Assessments by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), Food Security and Nutrition Analysis Unit (FSNAU) and Famine Early Warning Systems Network (FEWSNET) also indicate that, in the absence of humanitarian assistance, up to 2.1 million people across Somalia are expected to face food consumption gaps or depletion of assets indicative of Crisis (IPC Phase 3) or worse outcomes through December 2020.In addition, 849 900 children under the age of five are likely to be acutely malnourished through August 2021 . Crisis (IPC Phase 3) outcomes are expected from June to September in parts of central Somalia, where livestock holdings are lowest, and in northeasternSomalia, where the economy is more dependent on livestock, seafood, and frankincense exports. The socioeconomic impacts of COVID-19have led to a 30-50 % decline in annual external remittances, an anticipated 25-35 % decline in annual livestock exports, lower labour demand, and above average imported staple food prices.
Besides adverse weather conditions and conflict resulting in food insecurity and hunger, other prevailing challenges in the project areas Oxfam and partners Candlelight, Havoyoco and KAALO work are poor access to water and inadequate hygiene and sanitation conditions, as well as displacement. Against this backdrop,  the proposed activities aim at assisting both IDPs and host communities. Access to clean and safe water is a major area of concern in our intervention areas in Somaliland and Puntland.
Our proposed activities focus on relieving the distress suffered by affected families, preventing their situation from getting worse and strengthening collective resilience mechanisms. In terms of sectors we will focus on Food Security <(>&<)> Livelihoods (FSL), Water, Sanitation <(>&<)> Hygiene (WASH), Protection (PRO), Multi-Purpose Cash (MPCT) and Accountability (ACC).
Oxfam and partners Candlelight, Havoyoco and KAALO will work in the following regions and districts/locations: Awdal (Baki), Sool (Las Anod, Xudun, Bocaame), Sanaag (Eerigavo), Bari (Bossaso), Mudug (Jariiban). Partners have been implementing SOMJR activities in these regions and locations since 2019 (Awdal, Sool, Sanaag) and 2020 (Bari, Mudug), and were able to invest in the resilience building of target communities. Bocaame in Sool has been added as a new location to the SOMJR: it has already been targeted by partner KAALO during the DRA-funded Desert Locust Joint Response (May to October 2020), however, needs remain high as Bocaame is highly affected by insecurity and recurring waves of desert locust invasions.

title: Supporting Pastoralism and Agriculture in Recent and Protracted Crises (SPARC)
description: The Supporting Pastoralism & Agriculture in Recurrent & Protracted Crises (SPARC) programme will help poor and vulnerable people better cope with crises and increase their resilience to recurring shocks and protracted crisis and conflict by addressing evidence gaps on the effectiveness of different programmes and policies supporting, rebuilding, and increasing the resilience of agricultural livelihoods. As a result of the programme more people will have access to quality agricultural support during protracted and recurrent crisis.

title: CO-Response To Emergency in Somaliland
description:
To ensure and address the immediate food needs of target communities in Sool and Sanaag who are facing food insecurity levels of IPC 4, 3.500 HHs (21:000 individuals: 12.390 female, 8.610 male), they will receive multi purpose cash transfer for a period of three months, mitigating the impact of the drought throughout the lean season.
The livelihood component of this intervention will protect both household and community assets through the protection of core breeding animal by provision of fodder to vaccinated animals, targeting 90.000 head of livestock, benefiting 9.000 HHs (54.000 individuals; 31.860 female and 22.140 male). Training and provision ofveterinary start-up kits for 40 Community Animal Health Workers will benefit 3.600 households for treatment of their livestock.
In the WASH component of the action these communities directly benefit from a comprehensive package of immediate access to safe water, sanitation facilities and improved hygiene practices, including Cash for Water for 3 months for 1.760 of the most vulnerable households, improved storage capacity by provision of 16 communal water tanks, 2 jerry cans per household, and 420 emergency latrines for 4.167 HH (25.002 people), improved access to water by provision of fuel for 5 strategic borehole generators for 3 months, and maintenance of the boreholes will benefit 25.000 individuals (4.167 HH). To promote a safe water chain, Oxfam will distribute water treatment tablets for 3 months to cash for water recipients through hygiene promotion activities, for point of use household water treatment, with a focus on community engagement and participation. This will be accompanied by promotion of the adoption of good hygiene practices. Oxfam will also focus on community engagement initiatives including action planning, periodic review meetings on progress and programme processes, as well to obtain community feedback on the implementation modalities. Community volunteers will be trained on safe water chain, transmission route of water and sanitation related diseases, and preparation of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to promote adoption of good hygiene practices and manage dehydration amongst communities.
All this will be further supported throughprotection interventions. An ongoing protectionanalysis will ensure that activities can adapt to changes in the protection situation, that protection trend information can be shared with appropriate stakeholders, and that advocacy can be carried out where appropriate and necessary. Information on protection and existing services will be disseminated to women and men in target communities so that they are able to make informed decisions when faced with a protection threat or issue. WaSH and EFSL community committees and volunteers will be trained on protection risk analysis, and on how to receive and transmit protection information responsibly. A totalof 3.500 households will benefit from better information and a improved programming as a result.'

title: CO-Swiss Development Project in Somalila
description:
The project contributes to resilience  building in somaliland, as part of SOMREP effort to addressing the root causes of volubilities.
This project will build  the capacity of people to adopt  climate related Hazards through livelihood diversification, skills development, income generation and community based capacity building,the project will be implemented in Ceel-Afwayn and will be a threeyear period project.
The project is expected to build the resilience  of the community to withstand recurrent  droughts taking place in the area. the nature  of activities  will build on the on going humanitarian responses and act as Nexus between humanitarian and development.

title: CO-50
description: Oxfam in Somalia aims to compare available Google Trends data for Somalia, and Somaliland specifically, with data from existing research and MEAL systems from Oxfam in Somalia and local partners. We will determine if Google Trends data can be used to monitor changes in social norms around women/youth political participation.

title: HO-503001
description: Oxfam in Somalia aims to compare available Google Trends data for Somalia, and Somaliland specifically, with data from existing research and MEAL systems from Oxfam in Somalia and local partners. We will determine if Google Trends data can be used to monitor changes in social norms around women/youth political participation.

title: CO-Contribution To Humanitarian Response
description:
Based on the assessed humanitarian needs and projections for 2019, the response strategy remains focused on a two-pronged approach:

1.) To provide urgent life-saving, life-sustaining and dignity upholding assistance in response to food insecurity, water shortage, disease outbreak and protection risks that are faced as a result of recurrent drought.
2.) Investing in resilience and recovery interventions to work with communities, government institutions and other key stakeholders towards a more sustainable solution to the cyclical disasters in Somalia.

Overall Goal: To meet the immediate life-saving needs of 500,000 drought affected people and providesustainable solutions to improve the coping capacity of vulnerable communities to the effects of drought.

It must be stressed thatcross-cutting the entire humanitarian strategy is a commitment to localisation, safe programming working closely alongside local partners, line ministries and communities in implementing the response and recovery interventions, building capacity and longer-term sustainability along the way.

title: CO-Emergency response in Somalia
description: The project will ensure access to clean portable water with water-point rehabilitation and Cash for Water initiative in times of crisis (e.g. dry season or failed rains); improved sanitation through construction of HH shared latrines and provision of latrine cleaning kits; and improved hygiene practices with hygiene promotion and key inputs (particularly targeting the menstrual hygiene needs of women and girls of reproductive age). The Food Security and Livelihoods component of the project will deliver Multi-Purpose Cash to assist vulnerable households to access food and other necessities. Oxfam will collaborate with the Ministry of Livestock in a livestock vaccination campaign to treat the most common endo and ecto parasites to improve animal health in pastoralist communities, and will further work with vulnerable youth and women to diversify their livelihoods with vocational skills training and piloting of Voluntary Savings Groups. This will help increase employability and income, and will also contribute to building the capacity of women to take a more active role in decision making in their communities. The project will incorporate specific community protection activities engaging community protection volunteers, existing community committees and women#s groups to raise and mitigate protection risks at community level. Oxfam will map available services in target communities and engage with service providers on confidential referral pathways. Trainings on basic protection principles, rights and responsibilities will target community committees, women#s groups, community protection volunteers and relevant authorities will be capacity built to strengthen regional and national protection mechanisms.

implementing: The Norwegian Refugee Council is an independent humanitarian organization helping people forced to flee, tarted their relief efforts after World War Two, humanitarian needs were critical. They still are # and NRC still there, protecting people forced toflee and supporting them as they build a new future. Today, NRC work in both new and protracted crises across 31 countries NRC provide camp management, food assistance, clean water, shelter, legal aid, and education. displaced people's rights and dignityin local communities, with national governments and in the international arena. NRC#s Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre in Geneva is a global leader in monitoring, reporting on and advocating for people displaced within their own country.

title: CO-Covid-19 Protection Intervention
description:
As part of COVID19 preparedness and response  Oxfam and Shaqodoon local partner in collaboration with ministry of health and Telesom company have jointly set up and launched an interactive COVID-19 call center in Hargeisa. The call center plays a vital role in the dissemination of up-to-date and accurate and reliable information to the public, it provides prerecorded prevention guidelines; audio-based symptoms pre-screening options; counseling and medical assistance from health professionals and referrals to the emergencyand quarantine centers nearby. The center also feeds the government a way of tracking suspect cases information for emergency action and is alternative mechanism  for those have not physical access to government health facilities related to COVID. The call centerhas a toll free 24/7 available short code number (988) accessible from all over the country with 14 dedicated call agents who handle and process calls and voice messages, 2 professional doctors available for the management of suspect cases who provide counseling on daily bases to the callers and 2 technical assistance.
The call center receives 294,427 calls since its inception. Shaqodoon sends daily reports of the center including information of the suspect cases to the ministry of health to inform their daily plans regarding COVID19.
some of the Major project activities are :
- Supporting your partners in adapting to Covid-19 situation so that they can continue to provide protection services
- Adapting referrals to the newsituation # remotely?
- Supporting Protection committees to adapt their activities/ prepare for activities during lockdown (e.g. material needed, technical advice)
- Preparing to stay in touch with communities if movement restrictions get stricter (e.g.communication systems needed)
- Remote protection monitoring

title: CO-Response of Locust Infestation
description:
On 2nd February 2020 the Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation of the Federal Government of Somalia has declared a national emergency (see press statement in attachment) in view of the current Desert Locust upsurge that poses a major threat to Somalia#sfragile food security situation. Food sources for people and their livestock are at risk. The Desert Locust swarms are uncommonly large and consume huge amounts of crops and forage.
According to locust office of the Ministry of Agriculture and HADMA  latest report, there were huge swarm of Desert locust from Yemen that at the end September 2019 laid eggs in many locations in Somaliland. Despite controlefforts, a serious and widespread desert locust outbreak is threatening crops and pasture across Northern Somali regions. Accordingto experts, this is the worst outbreak in over 25 years in Somalia.

The situation has rapidly deteriorated in January 2020, as weather conditions have been unusually conductive to the spread of the pest. After cyclone Pawanmade landfall in early December 2019, flooding across the Horn of Africa created favourable breeding conditions for desert locusts. These conditions allow the breeding until June 2020 and could lead to 500 times more locust with the formation of large numbers of swarm as FAO indicated in their latest Appeal .
Desert Locust breeding is ongoing in Somaliland, Puntland and Galmudug (Mudug). An estimated 70,000 hectares of land has been invaded by hoppers and breeding adults. Once they mature the locusts areexpected to migrate in swarms and move south towards the Ethiopian border area of Somaliland as well as Jubaland, Southwest State and Hirshabelle. These swarms will be at their most destructive stage and pose a very severe risk to Deyr season food and fodder production.
Mating adults, hoppers and swarms have been detected in Northwest Somalia (between Bulhar and Silil). Hoppers and immature adults were reported on the Northwest plateau and a swarm was detected between Burao and the Ethiopian border. Hopper bands were also reported south of Bossaso, south of Las Anod (near the Ethiopian border) and in Galmudug (near Galkayo). More swarms are likely to form along the Northwest coast and plateau, which may migrate to Djibouti, Eastern Ethiopia and SouthernSomalia.
Crop and pastures have already been damaged in Somalia impacting negatively onagropastoral and pastoral households. In December 2019, it was reported that a huge number of desert locust (still at the stage of hopper bands) hatched in differentbreeding areas of Somaliland, such as coastal areas and farming land, posing a new devastating threat to crops and pasture lands.

title: CO-Covid-19  Spread Prevention In Somali
description:
Oxfam and our partners believe that accurate and reliable information on Covid-19 will save lives: currently, we are already responding and reaching more than 40,000 people directly with WASH services and more than 650,000 people in Somaliland and Puntland via the Covid-19 helplines this proposal seeks to support.  Toll-free Covid-19 helplines our partner Shaqodoon is running in the Ministries of Health in Somaliland and Puntland have been launched in mid-April and beginnning of May respectively. The call centres utilize an interactive voice response system providing up to date information related to Covid-19 to the community. People can call the hotline and receive WHO-approved pre-recorded messages on COVID-19, check symptoms, and also talk to a healthofficers if they wish to doso. They can also leave a voicemail and will be called back. The system can be accessed free of charge through mobile phones for callers using a 3-digit shortcode.
The Somaliland hotline has registered more than 651,366 callsso far (as of 19 May), highlighting the thirst of people across Somaliland for accurate and reliable information on Covid-19.  A number of risk cases have been identifiedthrough the helplines already, and people tested as a result of their call and guidance received. Shaqodoon is highlighting common misinformation on Covid-19 gathered through calls as well as stats on calls, follow-up and regional origin of callers on dashboards which support the Ministry of Health and humanitarian partners in addressing needs in a timely manner. They also produce weekly dashboards to provide the Ministry of Health with an overview of calls, levels of (mis-)information per region and necessary follow-up.

This project would support Shaqodoon in extending the helpline service in collaboration with the Ministries of Health for another 2months until June/July, reaching a majority of the population in Puntland and Somaliland (at least 60% of the population) with accurate and timely information, guidance and symptoms checking, while at the same time ensuring call center staff and Ministry of Health officials receive adequate protection and safe programming support to deal with sensitive data and critical cases.  Their work will be accompanied by the installment of innovative hands-free handwashing stations designed and produced in the TVET centres of partner Havoyoco. These measures will reach another 30,000 people across Somaliland.

Their work will be accompanied by the installment of innovative hands-free handwashing stations designed and produced in the TVET centres of partner Havoyoco. These measures will reach another 30,000 people across Somaliland.

title: CO-COVID-19 Oxfam Somalia Response
description:
In this part of the world where displacement and utmost poverty are prevalent with no properly
functioning health systems, it is hard to imagine how adversely impactful a COVID-19 outbreak will be.
People are already extremely vulnerable to bear yet another distressing crisis. While all countries need to
respond to COVID-19, countries with existing humanitarian crisis coupled with weak governance are
particularly vulnerable. When COVID-19 affects countries with protracted humanitarian crises like
Somalia/land, vulnerable populations, particularly women headed households, the disabled and the
elderly living in overcrowded camps or informal urban settlements will be highly vulnerable to the disease
and its social and economic impacts unless support is given on preventative measures.The number of
people in need of humanitarian assistance in Somalia, around 5.2 million currently, will likely sharply
increase in the event of COVID-19 outbreak making the already fragile situation much worse. The Locust
infestation is another evolving crisis andif not addressed will also have significant impact on the food
security and livelihoods of the people.
COVID-19 crisis will have a different and far-reaching impact on poor people, especially the vulnerable.
Anyone can be exposed to the virus but the poor are most vulnerable as they lack financial and social
protections. Overcrowded IDP settlements and poor urban slums are also going to be the places where
disease can spread easily and quickly. To effectively address the urgent and acute humanitarian dimension
of the crisis, we need to frame that within our understanding of how inequality plays out. Women will be
as susceptible to getting infected by the virus but their need for support is greater because, as in any crisis,
women including elderly women, bear the greater responsibility of caring for the family and making both
ends meet. Women#s multiple burdens of needing to contribute to the household income while also taking
care of the young, theelderly and the sick mean they have the longest days, the shortest rest and the
highest stress, making them easy targets of disease.
Containment measures and their economic fallout are likely to hurt more than the disease itself, and for
longer. Restrictions on movement and market access will affect many households# income and coping
strategies in Somalia/land, including households who were relatively well off before the pandemic. As well
as short term support we need to consider howto provide support to those affected over the longer term.

title: CO-COVID-19 Spared Reduction in Somalia
description:
6. Planned activities
a. WASH
- Improve personal hygiene and social distancing practice through awareness raising  on Covid-19
- Install functional handwashing centers in main IDP camp entrances, health facilities, main market areas with higher risk and other selected areas.
- Support for disinfection of screening centers, isolation centers, health facilities and other priority areas.
- Purchase and distribute hygiene kits to promote handwashing with soap at household level.
- Emergency water supply and construction of latrines for isolation, health facilities, and IDPs/host communities with water shortages (cash to access water)
b. FSL
- Support and improve roll out of inclusive social assistance through a minimum of four months# remote cash and/or vouchers, delivered to female headed households
- Livelihood inputs and technical assistance to support vulnerable population groups affected by the pandemic
c. Protection
- Provide protection support  to COVID-19 call center in Puntland.
- Provide protection and safe programming  training for frontline health workers operating in Oxfam areas of intervention and call center teams.
- Support existing community based protection structures e.g community volunteers, women#s forums to conduct community level awareness raisings on COVID-19 prevention provide PPE kits.
- Carry out specific service map that covers  information and service delivery of COVID19. An update on protection and emergency services will also be included e.g availability, accessibility etc.

title: CO-Response To  Cyclone Crisis in Somali
description:
The program will be achieved through focusing on unconditional cash transfer transfers targeting the most vulnerable IDPs and host communities affected by COVID 19 economically and exacerbated by GATI cyclone, based on the food consumption scoring and loss of livelihood assets. This intervention forms approximately 70% of the total cash transfer programming under Oxfam’s overall response and will be implemented directly by Oxfam by engaging electronic financial service provider in Puntland via mobile phones. Beneficiarieswho don’t possess Sim-cards will receive them as part of this response and be trained on its usage. The overall Oxfam food securityintervention which this contributes towards will include additional emergency livelihoods and recovery elements including cash for work interventions to rebuild destroyed feeder roads.Oxfam targets households that meet the critical food insecurity criteria takingintoconsideration gender-differentiated needs. The selection criteria will be discussed with thetarget women, men, boys and girls toensure fairness of the selection process. Usually, women are registered as beneficiaries and the head of the household for cash transfers. At times we find that some polygamous households are includedduring registration stage and this is addressed during verification, ensuring that the most vulnerable HH are Commented [AC12]: In addition to these activities DEC funds can also be used to coverany hygiene promotion activities/hygiene kits, COVID messaging, PPE for staffif needed?Commented [MH13R12]: We Have some PPE in thefield, Moses to add purchase of some PPE in the budget
targeted, in collaboration with community leaders. Female-headed households are the most affected as they do not have access to meaningful household assets such as livestock, or other sources of income. In Bari region, priorities for livelihood regeneration activities are different for women and men. Oxfam will deliver emergency food security interventions through cash grants for the most vulnerable people, while supporting household income by strengtheningand diversifying livelihoods through other projects. Oxfam's programming since March 2017 has successfully diversified the source of livelihoods in traditional pastoralist communities in Somaliland with plansto replicate this expereicnce in Puntland. This intervention will help vulnerable households to have some disposable income which they can use to purchase or meet their household food needs.Most vulnerable community members that will be most in need of the emergency assistance through this action will be identified through participatory mapping exercises conducted at village level through specific exercises including well-being rankings, vulnerability mapping, food consumption score, household purchasing power, among others. Gender will be consideredwhen selecting households to help reduce the additional burden on women headedhouseholds. The criteria shall be clearly explained to the selection committee/panel prior toselection, with clearcommunication on what beneficiaries will be entitled to during the project, to avoid unrealistic expectations.

title: CO-EFSL & WASH Based COVID-19 Response
description: Somalia is one  of the  most  fragile and complex humanitarian crises in  the world. The country is emerging from more than three decades of conflicts with weak formal government systems since the collapse of the central  governmentin  the  early  1990s.Decades  ofarmed  conflicts  coupled  with  recurrent  drought conditions,  famine,  persistent  food  insecurity,  protracted  population  displacement  as  well  as  seasonal flooding  have left the country suffering one of the world’s worst humanitarian  situations.  The southern Somalia  has  been  the  worst  affected  with  the  region  experiencing  cycles  of  conflict  that  have  destroyed legitimate  institutions  and  created  widespread  vulnerability.  While  situation  was  dire  alreadydueto protracted  conflicts and drought, COVID 19 pandemic emergence detoriorated both health and livelihood sources of Somali community. In DEC phase 2, Oxfam plans to provide an integrated WASH and food security project to support emergency food  crises and  support  recovery  of livelihoods lost  due  to  drought  or  COVID  19  pandemic  in  Puntland, Jubaland and Somaliland administrative regions of Somalia. EFSVL Component: The project will addresshumanitarian needs of the IDPs, poor urban and returnees and will support cash and voucher assistance(CVA) to people affected by triple threats of conflict, drought and COVID 19 economically. This will be complemented to supportingLivelihood restoration for women groups affected  by  COVID  pandemic toenable  them to resume  or  establish  viable  livelihood options  intended  to provide  sustainable  livelihood  opportunities  for  affected  IDPs,  returnees  and  host  community  in  target 11regions of Somalia. This outcome will alleviate the sufferingof 6,780 people from extreme effects of COVID 19 i mpact and improve their food security situation. WASH Outcomes: A total of 8000people are expected to benefit from rehabilitation of three strategic water points  coupled  by  hygiene  and  promotion activities.  COVID  19  awareness  raising  will  be  conducted  for 60,000people  in  all  target  regions  of  the  project  with  the  aim  of  reducing  spread  of  this  pandemic. This outcome will benefita total of 60,000people. The project will benefita total of 60,000peopleand will be implemented in the same districts as DEC phase 1 in Puntland and Somaliland while the project target Kismayo district of Lower Juba region. Oxfam continues to work with WASDA in this project and implementationmodalitywill remain mixed approach.  The activities are in line with Oxfam’s Humanitarian Strategy forSomalia and contributes to our Oxfam Coutnry Strategy (OSC)2020-2025.

title: CO-Drought & Sever Water Shortages Respo
description:
2020 was one of the hardest years for Somalia in decades. Flooding, COVID-19 and recurring locust invasions heavily impacted on theeconomy and livelihoods of people. The government implemented measures to contain COVID-19, including the closure of schools, reduction of movement and other economic activities. The coastal areas of Puntland and Somaliland were also hit by cyclone Gati in November 2020, resulting in a sharp increase in humanitarian needs which many organizations - including Oxfam Somalia - responded to. While the performance of the 2020 Gu rain was near normal, the Deyr rain of 2020 has been categorized a complete failure due to the La Nina conditions. These developments triggered severe water shortages in many regions and districts in Somalia. Since October 2020, regional administrations, communities and other humanitarian agencies have been sending alerts about looming drought conditions in many parts of Somalia.Oxfam’s feedback hotline continues to receive a high number of calls from people requesting immediate water interventions. These callers are mainly from the Sool, Sanaag and Togdheer regions. UNOCHA assessment findings indicate that over 50% of the communities in the assessed locations reported displacement of people due to water shortages, 85% raised major concerns on watershortages, and 14 out of 40 villages reported an increase in diarrheal cases. The price of water has already more than doubled. According to Oxfam’s own market assessment, one barrel of water is currently being sold at an average of USD 4.5 per barrel, with some villages reporting over USD 7 per barrel. This is forcing the most vulnerable households to travel long distances to fetch water and/or opt for poor water quality and risk their lives. The most affected communities include IDPs and low-income host communities. Women and girls are at risk of protection-related risks as they travel in search of water.
Regarding COVID-19, over 4,784 cases with over 130 fatalities were registered by the WHO in Somalia since the start of the pandemic, with many cases left undetected due to asymptomatic infections, low testing capacity and the stigmatisation of COVID-19 cases among the population. The second wave of the pandemic seems to have also hit the country as the number of cases started to increase in the last few months. The government of Somaliahas eased most of the restrictions in August 2020 and most of the public services have resumed. This increases the risk of vulnerability to COVID-19 and the shortages of water in many areas further restrict the communities' ability to frequently wash their hands with soap. This might create a favourable environment for COVID-19 to spread.
The Ministry of Water Development in Somaliland shareda request with all humanitarian agencies, indicating that over 196,848 people are in need of urgent water interventions and that many others also require quick rehabilitations of their water sources. Over 88% of the people in need are from the Sool, Sanaag, and Togdheer regions of Eastern Somaliland. In October 2020, Oxfam using the ECHO crisis modifier budget reached the most vulnerable 1,800 HH (10,800 people) in Sool, Sanaag, and Togdheer for 30 days with WASH interventions. Since then, we have continued to advocate for urgent interventions by sharing summary reports with the Somalia WASH cluster and presentations of the situation with cluster members. Utilising other existing resources, we are also working with the Ministry of Water Resources to rehabilitate boreholes that were identified as strategic wells by the government.

title: Innovative Fishery Development
description:
The first component is aimed at capacity building. At least 40 beneficiaries (at least 30% female) including fishermen and women, fishmongers will undergo a maximum of six months theoretical and practical training. Youth fishermen and women will be trained on safety at sea, fishing gear mending and repairs, safe fishing methods and fish preservation, cooperatives establishment and fish quality assurance. Fishmongers, who will mostly be women, will be trained in various topics including fish handling and preservation, fishprocessing, personal hygiene, value addition (processing, grading, and packaging) and small business management. Entrepreneurship will be an integral part of the courses in order to leverage the entrepreneurship capacity
The second component is aimed at supporting the establishment/ strengthening of fishery organizations. The target beneficiaries will be organized in Self Help Groups (SHGs). The SHG is a rights-based approach which views poverty as the denial of rights and poverty alleviation as a process of reclaiming one’s rights. Given the multi-dimensional nature of poverty, the SHG Approach puts equal emphasis on the goals of economic, social andpolitical empowerment . Therefore, the established/strengthened SHGs will have the potential to empower small-scale fishers againstsome of the environmental and socioeconomic shocks such as fish catch shortfalls and revenues, sickness and death in their families, natural disasters and hunger. The 30 young fishermen will be organized intoat least 5 SHGs and will be trained/ oriented on the operations of the SHGs
The third component will support the distribution of fishing kits/gear to the SHGs including women fishmongers.Midway through the training, the project beneficiaries will be provided with fishing gears in their SGHs. Such gear may include boats and other necessary tools. On the other hand, women fishmongers, will have business start-up kits including refrigerators and basic fish processing tools. The fishing kits/ gear will be owned and managed jointly in the SHGs.
The fourth component will focus on learning and knowledge management through value chain research. In order to ensure systematic market mapping in the fishing sector, understand actors, market share, capacity gaps, and other relevant value chain information, the project will undertake a robust research on fish value chain. The research will aim to bring out suitable models to link small holders to input and output markets and improve the benefits that fishermen and women and other resource-poor value chain actors derive from the chain. Knowledge generated from the research will be disseminated to different relevant stakeholders in the sector. It will also act as a building block for future scaling efforts of the project. As Oxfam and the partner have both long-term livelihood strategies, the research finding would beused for future programing.

title: Strengthening  Capacity of Nexus Members
description:
Somalia, a fragile State that is emerging from decades of civil war, is currently experiencing an unprecedented situation mainly caused by climate change, Covid-19 and locust infestation, which exacerbated the long-term existed challenges within the country including widespread vulnerability and marginalization, insecurity and government with poor institutional capacity to deliver and advocate for basic humanitarian needs of local communities, combination of the above mentioned challenges contributed to negative socio-economic impact on Somali communities and resulted in the displacement of affected populations (mainly rural) and formation of IDP sites alongside main towns.
Other challenges encountered by Somalia and Somaliland communities include lack of coping capacity to climate change and widespread dependency created by Humanitarian Aid due to the absence of government’s role that affects the livelihood of entire communities rather than building their long-term resilience. It's evident that the Humanitarian Aid Dependency has largely affected the productivity of the Somali population. However, there's need to exhaust to what extent these will be addressed by our research questions for the Participatory Action Research (PAR) on Aid Humanitarian Aid dependency.
In 2019, nine Somali NGOs founded the Nexus platform that aims to shape the future in Somalia and Somaliland, by creating an enabling environment for Somali NGOs to have a leading role in the humanitarian system that puts the agency and self-reliance of communities at the center, through delivering a combination of Humanitarian Aid, Development, and Peace interventions. The Nexus coalition is led by nine Somali NGOs – African Development Solutions (ADESO), Centre for Peace and Democracy (CPD), Gargaar Relief and Development Organization (GREDO), Horn of Africa Voluntary Youth Committee (HAVOYOCO), KAALO, Save Somali Women and Children (SSWC), Social-Life and Agriculture Development Organisation (SADO), Taakulo Somaliland Community (TASCO), and WASDA. Two INGOs – Oxfam and Save the Children International were invited to join as international partners to support with critical investments.
So far the platform developed and applied its strategy andtheory of change whilst Humanitarian actions are the platform’s immediate priority in its current scope of work, Somalia Nexus consortium aims to focus interventions that are in line with its pillars, including Community-driven and working across the Triple Nexusof Development, Humanitarian Aid, Peace-building and conflict-resolution, as well as strengthening the capacity of Somali Civil Society <(>&<)> Government institutions. In addition, special considerations will be given concerning practicality and implementation methodology including presence, scaleof the need, duration and coordination with other stakeholders.
The day-to-day activities of theplatform are performed by the Secretariat supported by the Steering committee who are also responsible for resource mobilization, organizing coordination meetings, fund management and drafting policies and guidelines
In 2021, the Nexus platform aims to implement efforts to support its members and government institutions in both Somalia and Somaliland, through development of Community-driven Development manuals, conducting Participatory Action Research that finds durable solutions on climate related challenges in both pastoral and agro-pastoral communities, conducting PAR that aims to address the level and scope of dependency created by Unconditional Cash disbursement to local rural communities as well as supporting Somalia and Somaliland governments to develop standardized Cash Transfer model with clear guidelines.
Social inclusion, protection and Covid-19 protocols will be maintained and mainstreamed in project interventions.

title: CO-Rapid Assessment CFM
description:
Oxfam’s commitment is to actively centre the voice and experience of people and community in all our work and consider power, privilege and equity in the design of community-based feedback and complaints mechanisms CBFCMS, and to respect the knowledge, wisdom andperspective of others, as there is always scope for Oxfam to grow and learn as an organisation working with communities.
Functionalfeedback and complaints mechanisms that are accessible and safe to use are a demonstration of our organization-wide accountability commitment, to be truly accountable to the people and communities we work with and those affected by our programmes, by ensuring that they understand what is appropriate and inappropriate conduct of our staff and partners, getting their feedback about our programmes and/or complaints about conduct of our staff, agents or partners  and taking appropriate action to address these concerns. Accountability is “the process of using power responsibly, taking account of, and being held accountable by different stakeholders, and primarily those who are affected by the exercise of such power” . It is the right to be heard, and the duty to respond.

However, anecdotal information indicates that where CBFCMs initiatives and experiences exist in Oxfam, many are still disjointed, some are uncoordinated, and largely undocumented. In many places, they are non-existent, or if they are, not all of them are fully functional. The design of Oxfam’s CBFCMs by Affiliates, Country Offices and in part Partners has not always ensured community involvement, in most cases resulting in not fit for purpose mechanisms. Also different affiliates still approach the issue of CBFCMs differently with different emphasis, approaches, tools and resources, therefore lacking a standardised coordinated approach.

Although Oxfam prides itself for encouraging communities we work with to speak out and report PSEA and child protection concerns and incidents concerning them,recent reports in some countries like DRC, Ethiopia, and Uganda not only attests to the limited awareness at community level on SEAand child protection risks and reporting mechanisms, but has also led to an increase in attention to ensure that SEA and child abuse and exploitation by humanitarian and development organisations like Oxfam are addressed through investment in preventive approaches but also responding to reports of abuse and exploitation when these incidents are reported.
Oxfam has two responsibilities for accountability in the programmes it manages, holding a responsibility for mutual accountability with its partners (as do the partners) and also holding a shared or joint accountability (with its partners) to the communities affected by its programmes. There is lack of knowledge how the
In addition to some of the above challenges, COVID-19 has added additional challenges to how effective current CBFCMs are, placing additional barriers to reporting that are currently not fully understood or risks mitigated.
OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT:
1. Map out existing CBCM’s initiatives in select field/project locations, and document best practices and lessons learnt in implementing CBFCMs across the Oxfam confederation
2. Undertake a rapid assessment of the existing CBFCMs in Oxfam terms of effectiveness, experiences and lessons plus existing gaps.

title: Supporting on Borehole Drill  in Somalia
description:
The eastern regions in Somaliland and especially Saanag and Sool regions continue to suffer from recurrent drought. This situation has increased the vulnerability of the communities as they have lost most of their livestock which was their main source oflivelihood. The situation is exacerbated by the fact that the two regions also continue to experience occasional inter clan fighting which isoften triggered by competition for available pasture and water resources. Drilling of the a boreholes will not only contribute to providing important water sources that can support the water needs of the communities during drought and harsh climatic conditions, but also contribute to reducing risk factors leading to conflict. It will offer an opportunity to the benefiting communities to have a chance for better access to potable water, reduce the incidents water related diseases and increase access for water for practicing frequent handwashing to prevent COVID-19.
Objectives;
• Provide sustainable water source for 5000 people and over 10,000 livestockheads in Sanaag Region.
Groundwater Feasibility Study:
A groundwater feasibility study will be conducted in three selected villagesof Sanaag region. the study will follow three approach method,
1. Remote Sensing: Desk review using latest satellite imageries to selected best possible locations. This phase will focus on finding regional fractures carrying water from highland of Ethiopia to thelowland of Sanaag regions and from Sanaag mountains to low land areas.
2. Geophysical Study: ground truthing work will be conducting using latest start of art geophysical technology at least three locations with spacing of 1000 -1500m. This location are those selected in first phase of the study work. Government and community engagement will be conducted to understand the local geology, possible impact of drilling on environment and stability of the communities.
Drilling of the borehole
Based on the groundwater feasibility study, the drilling work will be advertised through the local media. In order to avoid failures resulted from improper use of drilling equipment and selection of drilling method, the contractor will receive full copy of the study report and will be given a briefing on the drilling technology and technique recommended by the study team. Then, a payment by result approach will be used to contract drilling companies i.e. Oxfam/Taakulo will only pay if the borehole has water with discharge of above 2liter per second. Failureto get a contractor willing to commence drilling with such conduction, further meeting will be help between Oxfam and Taakulo to discuss best possible approach to increase value for money.
Supervision and Monitoring:
In drilling works supervision and monitoring progress is critical step. Oxfam/Taakulo will have a site supervisor equipped with necessary materials for supervision including TDS Sensor to record water quality at each 1 meter, mud funnel to record the drilling mud viscosity and deeper to follow the depth of the drilling. The supervisor will provide daily update to both Oxfam/Taakulo team and will ensure all decision that affect drilling performance is consulted and agreed before action. TDS level will be recorded in monitoring tool provided and the result will be used for deciding the borehole casing arrangement. All materials that will be used for drilling will be inspected by the drilling supervisor and approve. In case a specialized chemical will be used for the drilling; the supervisor will request for all safety related certificate prior use of such chemicals.
Post Drilling Construction:
This action will be decided right after the drilling is completed. Provision of submersible pump with cable and riser pipes, and construction of generator house, water distribution system for both animal and human and storage facilities will be included under this phase. Other grants, including ECHO 2021 and/or other internal grants will be used to finance this critical activity. Incase the borehole salinity is above an acceptable regional level i.e. 2500ppm, provision of desalination unit will be considered.

implementing: Taakulo Somali Community Commonly known by the acronym #TASCO#. TASCO is a multifaceted non-governmental, non-profit making, non-political and non-partisan development and humanitarian aid organization established in 2007 and headquartered in Hargeisa, Somaliland. Taakulo is a Somali word meaning #helping/aiding#. Working in partnership with UN, international, and National organizations, TASCO is dedicated to helping the disadvantaged people and communities throughout Somali by engaging in development and related activities and also providing relief support and assistance, facilitating and promoting participatory local community activities and programs that emphasize human dignity and self-reliance.

title: Mustaqbaldoon
description:
The project contributes to the development problem of the vulnerability of the youth which is manifested in youth unemployment and limited access to income causing risky survival strategies such as informal quasi-legal or illegal activities and as a conseq
uence social problems like violence early sexual activity and a range of economic physical and psychological risks.The principal outcomes of the project are 1) Strengthened Civil Society and Local Administration 2) Increased motivation of youth to contribu
te to the society and 3) Increased economic empowerment of youth. The central activities include capacitating the local CSOs and public administration turning the risky survival strategies of youth to healthy ones and 3) training youth to recognize local i
ncome generation opportunities instead of leaving the country.  Developing countries own economies have generated more jobs livelihood opportunities and well-being is the priority area of Finland's development policy the project is aimed at contributing to
. Somalia is ranked as one of the bottom five countries in terms of gender inequality and therefore positive discrimination and affirmative measures will be taken to enhance the participation of young women and girls and to raise awareness about their part
icular needs. The project aims to reduce inequality by emphasizing the rights of all youth as full and equal members of the communities where they live. Project respects climate sustainability too.The project capacitates CSOs and public administration to w
ork with private sector according to multi-stakeholder approach. Helsinki Deaconess Institutes Vamos services is acknowledged in a national level as a unique concept to support vulnerable youth's access to education and employment. The same concept will be
 used together with cooperation partners Y-PEER in Hargeisa and Gedo Development in Gedo. The principal beneficiaries of the project are the youth (15-35 years) who have dropped out from education and employment.

title: Mobile platform for employment creation
description:
The goal of the 12-monthproject is expanding opportunities for youth through innovative alternative financing for Startup#s and ignite new breed of entrepreneurs-and providing supporting service for entrepreneurs. the  aim is  to achieve this goal through three main objectives:
1. Support the creation of new breed of start-up, through alternative financing, acceleration and incubation.
2.ducate,  engage  and  connect  entrepreneurs  through  regular  meetups  and  educational experience sharing.
3. ntroduce alternative mid-size financing model, through the development of dedicated locally developed crowdfunding platformand matching-equity-basedfinancing for startups while attracting further funds fromfinancial institutions to scale up.
In total, thisproject is expected to ignite up to15Enterprisesandprovide them with access to financial and non-financial  services  that  build  or  expand  these  businesses  with  the  objective  ofcreating  an  additional 45 directjobs for youth. The start up huddlewill attract up to 720 attendees of which about 15will ignite or expand their business ideas after attending the Startuphuddlewhich will create additional 30 jobs bring thetotal 75 new employment opportunities.

title: CO-Somalia Resilience Program
description:
The program promotes bottom-up and top-down governance capacity development.  At HH and group level, the program will continue to expand the number of VSLAs, increasing the number of these social capital-developing and integration-promoting mechanisms.  Through the intensive GCVCA facilitated assessment process and subsequent development of CAAPs, SomReP will continue to place the community at the forefront of analyzing their own challenges and opportunities, and putting forth their own priorities and plans to help them better plan for and mitigate against shocks and promote food security and economic development.  The CAAP is the foundation for development planning at the community level, assisting community leadership to identify and prioritize development actions. Other organizations and consortia are also developing plans at community and district level; as such, SomReP will continue to jointly plan and coordinate actions at both Technical Unit and site level so as to ensure efficient use of multipledonors# resources in fulfillment of community needs.
In partnership with district and Member State line ministries, SomReP will undertake sector specific assessments targeting systems (e.g. water systems, market systems) which affect resilience buildingwithin and between villages.  During times of shock, SomReP will mobilize resources to partner with relevant line ministries to undertake assessment to support early response and post-shock recovery.  Village and village-cluster plans will be aggregated and support the development of district-level planning frameworks.  Through direct support to line ministries through secondments and other facilitative actions, the program will promote understanding of national and Member State Level frameworks (NDP andRRF) at the community planning level.  As Member State line ministries are supported to monitor uptake and progress towards achieving disaster risk management actions at community level, the government will both fulfill its mandate and begin to strengthen its ability to do this independently.

implementing: Somaliland National Disaster Preparedness and Food Reserve Authority( NADFOR) was established in 2003 but legally passed in June 2007 through parliament, house of elders and signed by the President of Somaliland , Nafor's goal is to prevent frequent occurrence ofdisasters, droughts and reduce vulnerability of communities by improving sustainable coping capacities to decrease overall impact to disasters on lives and livelihoods of Somaliland communities. NADFOR's Strategic Objective to become effective and efficient institution managing early warning systems, information sharing and dissemination advocating for disasters and related environmental crisis for strategic decision making and action in the country.
Somaliland National Disaster Prepar and Food Reserve Authority

implementing: The Puntland authorities established HADMA (Humanitarian Affairs and Disaster Management Agency) in 2005 to lead the coordination of humanitarian interventions in Puntland on a monthly basis. HADMA, with the support of OCHA currently coordinates and organizes sectoral meetings on: Health, Education, Water and Sanitation, Environment, Infrastructure and Shelter, Food Security and Fisheries. The Puntland Ministry of Planning and International Cooperation also do some coordination in terms of development programmes.
Humanitarian Affairs and Disaster Management Agency

title: CO-Learning champions among Oxfam projec
description: This project will strengthen learning within Oxfam as well as from local partnerships. It#s hoped that entailing local partners, documenting and sharing learnings from Oxfam-Partner and Partner-Partner interactions will prioritize the southern agenda. The developed tools will become part of the overall MEAL tools and the info-graphs and short videos will ensure that knowledge is shared throughout Oxfam and with partners

title: CO-Enhancing Resilience in Somaliland
description:
This project is aimed to enhance community resilience in Berbera area, as part of  bigger SOMREP effort in promoting resilience across Somalia and somaliland.
This Project focus on community capacity development to withstand shocks and stresses with particular focus on drought hazard.
key pilers of the project includes VSLAs establishment at community level: development community action plan,enhance youth entrepreneurship   and support on marketable IGAs.  The project will support access to food security at household level through provision  of agricultural input  to potential farmers. A Total of 30,000 people are expected to benefit this project fora period of one year.

title: CO-integrated humanitarian Somalia respo
description:
About 4.6 million people in Somalia are food insecure and 4.2 million are in need of humanitarian assistance. The reduction in the number of people in need since early 2018 has been attributed to favourable rainfall during the Gu season (April to June) and sustained humanitarian assistance. Over 1.5 million people face acute food security Crisis or worse (IPC Phase 3 or higher) and approximately 3.1 million people are Stressed (IPC 2)1. Although the 2016/2017 drought has ended in most parts of Somalia, its adverse impact lingers among those who were impoverished or displaced, and pastoralists who lost all or most of their livestock, particularly in the north. Without sustained food and livelihood assistance, the latter are likely to remain in Emergency (IPC 4).
While acute malnutrition rates have improved nationally to Serious from Critical, the overall prevalence of acute malnutrition remains largely unchanged from Deyr 2017/2018. Between August and December, 294,000 acutely malnourished children, including 55,000 severe cases, aged underfive, will require treatment and integrated support. The acute malnutrition burden over the next 12 months is projected to be 588,400 acutely malnourished children, including 110,500 severe cases. The persistently high levels of acute malnutrition are unlikely toreduce without addressing the underlying causes, particularly in internally displaced persons (IDP) settlements and in some rural areas

title: Oxfam in Somalia Influencing Project
description:
In line with the OCS and Humanitarian Advocacy Strategy, Oxfam#s standalone influencing activities will center on the following thematic areas:
1. Women#s Empowerment: addressing the deep and widespread gender gap, particularly foregrounding the influence of women#s rights organisations.
2. Localisation of Aid: agitating for change related to the persistent barriers towards localisation of aid in both humanitarian and development fields, in close alliance with local and national partners.
3. Debt Relief: in collaboration with the Debt Working Group, seeking expedited, full debt cancellation for Somalia at the highest levels.
4. Youth Empowerment: addressing the specific needs, challenges and aspiration of youth, particularly in terms of influence in decision-making, education and employment.
5. Protection: leveraging our humanitarian presence to identify key protection issues and influence for change, while also feeding into broader protection work, such as with the Regional Durable Solutions Secretariat.

implementing: Since 1993, World Vision has been working in areas of Somalia with the highest levels of child poverty. Our goal is to achieve long-lasting benefits in the quality of life for vulnerable children and their families, displaced persons, and communities using a development approach that increases participation, understanding and unity among people of different cultures while promoting the rightsand interests of Somali children. In response to the humanitarian needs of the Somali people, World Vision designs and delivers programs coordinated at regional and country levels by dedicated staff that provides strategic and operational support. Our program offices are located close to communities so our teams can be responsive to the needs of local children and their families at the community level. Following the 2011 famine and more than 20 years since the collapse of the central government, strong signs of hope areemerging for sustained peace, and the opportunity for families to live healthy, prosperous lives. World Vision is committed to walking with communities from emergency through rehabilitative programming in order to bring about sustainable and long-term change overthe coming years.
